content:
We have a security related design discussion for people to take a look at:
https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/3139#issuecomment-920296667

I feel the constraints are described well; some of them have not occurred to me.
I'm not yet familiar with the specific solutions being proposed (PASETO, Bisquit) so that's something I'd have to look up, but I see Tony has already chimed in
The prospect of hardware key storage support without creating a dedicated protocol just for it is particularly exciting
there are a number of existing agents for PIV which handle things like PIN entry which could be augmented to be cargo credential helpers
@Tony Arcieri can you elaborate on that?
also is there a recording of you Bay Area Rust Meetup talk?
@Eh2406 the main ones I know are written in Go although I know of people working on ones in Rust
https://github.com/smlx/piv-agent
Filippo Valsorda of the Go crypto team has also been working on one
re: the talk, well it was recorded on Air Mozilla, but it looks like after the latest reincarnation of Air Mozilla the video may have been lost
wish they just put them on youtube :oh_no:
hmm there are a bunch on YouTube, although I don't see that one in particular

@Tony Arcieri do we want to write an Inside Rust blog about OSV export?
I think we need more publicity in general, since the number of clones per day on advisory-db is still a small fraction of active Rust developers. This seems to be as good of an occasion as any.
sounds good to me
@nikomatsakis ^^^ idea for an Inside Rust blog post
Hmm, is the target for this post Rust users? or Rust team members?
Traditionally I have viewed Inside Rust as the latter
aah
yeah it's more user-oriented, although FWIW our other post was that way as well
yeah, there is a "other use" I guess of a kind of muted announcement path
(vs the full blog)
We don't really have a separate blog for the WG or for RustSec so we've effectively been using Inside Rust for announcements. If that's not a good fit, we can look for some other way
Inside Rust is intended primarily for 'people interested in the internals of Rust development', rather than just 'Rust users'
I don't know much about OSV export, but it sounds like the kind of thing that probably goes on the main blog
That's my thought too
It seems plausible to... just put it on the main blog to me
but I also don't really know what OSV Export is :)
https://forge.rust-lang.org/core/blogs.html

Basically, Google made a machine-readable format for vulnerability reports. And we export our data to it now.
Previously we either had either language-specific formats (like RustSec TOML) or data that's not machine-readable (like CVE).

Google also sponsored this work - as in, paid me to do it. So I may have a bit of a conflict of interest in this situation and would like an external perspective on how this announcement should be handled.
my understanding is this only matters to people writing tools to consume the rustsec dataset
so that might be more for inside rust

Pietro Albini said:

my understanding is this only matters to people writing tools to consume the rustsec dataset

Yes, that is correct
In any case, I think once we have a post it'll be easier to tell which blog it's better directed at :)

Another wrinkle is that since I have a bit of a conflict of interest, I can't write that post myself without going through pre-review by Google, which will take 2 weeks or so. So it's probably gonna be quicker to just do without my direct involvement.
